children.text: Explicit language
Racial Slur
Explicit language
Explicit language
Clip used for lesson
We'll have some questions. That may be useful and helpful, uh, to us, uh.
It's very, uh, very much important that you became a political prisoner, this is what you were, in many ways.
Not that we say you should atone [for this?] if you did, I don't know whether you did or didn't.
Maybe some of you did. But this we shouldn't have done, because we need discipline.
We have to have far more discipline than the white man if we're gonna win this, uh, struggle.
And the Mississippian is fighting a fool's battle. A battle that he has to lose.
And in winning it. We need control and restraint.
But when we strike, we strike where we're on good grounds.
But whether you threw a brick or didn't. The fact still remains. He used you as a tool.
As an instrument. He made something of a thing of you.
Because he was trying, by keeping you in jail, by setting a bond at $5,000 and finally reducing it to $500.
to strike fear in the hearts of your parents and other people in the community. He was trying to cut off one segment
of the Negroes of MCComb. from another segment, another part of the… city. He was trying to divide the people who live here
from those of us who are down at the Freedom House, attempting to work in the community to gain the kinds of justice, the kind of right action
and good living, that is necessary if any of us are going to live in a free America, particularly in the free Mississippi.
Now, you were used. Some of you, no doubt, will be bitter about it.
I know a lot of people were bitter the night the houses were bombed.
Bitterness alone is not going to suffice. If you're angry, good.
I mean, you have right to be angry. The question now is not whether you're angry
or you dislike somebody, but whether or not
you will take actions, take steps, to change the kind of city and county where people can be held in jail for things like this.
Where they can create a law to arrest any Negro or any white person in the movement on just about any charge they want to. They, you know… Give it a nice sounding name, they say "syndicalism."
Some of us, you know, stumble over it when we kind of pronounce the word.
But it still basically means that anyone tries to work for justice in our society
is doing something against the law. This is ironic, this is a mockery.
You know, during the next… few weeks, months, or years.
Everyone here in Mississippi and in the South is going to be embroiled in a battle.
And you're going to have to do something. This includes many things.
As students, you're going to have to speak in your community, and perhaps out of your community.
Tell people what's happening, to tell people why they must try and change this.

Those of you who are students are still at the same time going to have to be working very hard at your studies, so that you're not losing ground there as you're trying to win it over in another field.
You're going to have to be out canvassing, talking to people, doing something, to bring about justice --
unless you enjoyed being in jail. If you didn't enjoy it, then you must do something to change it.
And not simply turn your back and say, "it can't happen again," because it CAN happen again.
And it MIGHT happen tomorrow. Unless you're ready to do something.
Unless you, your friends, and your parents are ready to band together as a united people seeking to bring about a full, good, free society and world in which to live.
Let me point out one or two quick things.
We're going to have a rally. On Sunday night. we're going to have a Freedom Day on Monday.
Where we'll be working primarily with the adults, trying to get them to go to Magnolia and register.
To vote. You realize that if your parents -- and you -- were voters. This could not have happened to you.
Sheriff Warren, Chief Guy, Mayor Burt. You name anyone you want.
He's in power, he's in office. Because you don't vote. He treats you the way he does. Because you or your parents don't vote. And if you vote, out goes Warren.
We say goodbye to Guy and to Bert.
You can change it. You can do something. We're hoping that all of you --
I'm hoping, I'm sure you will, but… all of you will be at the rally.
On Sunday. Perhaps… Uh, Jesse will ask some of you to speak, to say something.
We want you there. I want the people to see you, to know who you are.
To know that you suffered something for them.
During the next few weeks, you'll be called on many times: Be ready and be available.
This is... little things that, on my mind.
If you all have any questions. fine. If not… [cough].
I think Dennis and Cephas have… Some questions that they wish to… to ask about conditions at the jail, and questions that were asked of you.
Dennis, did you first want to…
Yeah, I wanted to say a couple things. Some of you saw me when you first came in, when you were first picked up. I remember some of the faces.
I was… that was when I was in a cell downstairs, but I was -- I was out in a day.

And I just wanted to say about that sort of thing, that, um… I've thought, you know, 3 or 4 times since I've been out of jail, and you've still been in jail, what you must be thinking about, and how it must make you feel.
To know that, you know, a white civil rights worker can be picked up and out of jail in a day when you have to stay in jail and stay in jail and stay in jail.

And it's not fair, it's… It's, you know, I don't know what to say about it, except that… That's why we're… that's why we're down here, and that we're not gonna leave [cough] until such a time arrives that…
you know, people aren't treated that way. In other words, you know, I wasn't bailed out, I was just released. They tried to get ALS to testify against me, and… And fortunately…
He was courageous enough in the face of Sheriff Warren, and… Attorney Reeves to not do that kind of thing.
And so they had to drop the charges and let me go.
But, um… I just want to apologize for the way that system works in that particular case, and I know how you must feel.
And, um, that's really why, you know, we're here.
Um, the only thing, only question I had was… was about ALS, and… and he's…  he's told me already [cough] several things.
They said, I think it'd be important later on if John could get --Could get an affidavit from ALS as to what Reeves said to him.
All I want to say is welcome back.
[Laughter and exclamation]

Right now, everybody's, you know, ready to, um, fall back into the normal… uh procedures in life [clearing throat], you know, living, sort of, as we did before, but not… I hope not as completely as we did before.
[murmmuring of agreement]
Uh, no. maybe if you, uh, after you've had a chance to sleep on your own beds and uh, eat at your own table. Among your friends.
[murmmuring of agreement]
[unintelligible, laughter]
Go ahead, Larry.
Warden came out down there to jail a while ago -- as for [?] the fellow that were takin' our names he told us to come back every day. Do any of y'all --
[new voice] I didn't understand -- [cough]
I didn't understand his name or what he means about comin' --
He said something about court on the 20th.
I told him, he says tomorrow. He says appear every day. Until it's thrown out, [cough] the case is thrown out, yeah.
Um, that sounds, uh… Absolutely stupid to me. But we will check with our lawyer to make absolutely certain. we will, you know, find out.
Because we don't want them to-- pulling you back in on a technicality.
Um, they would try and do something as asinine as that.
That's all I'm saying.
But, uh… We want to check that out.
Um, any other questions of this nature? Alright.
A couple questions to you, and to the parents.

We ought to know, as we release this. Uh, what were the conditions there? First, in terms of the parents being able to get in and see the children. I know some were able, and some were not able to see their children.
I think it might be helpful for John and for us to know, situation-wise.

It was a week before I seen Willy. Before they let me see Willy. But I seen Father June, the day after they uh carried him up. Carried him down in Magnum[?]. But it was a week before they let me even see Willy.
That was Ms. Thomas
Can I say somethin'?
Sure.
What's goin on, how do you feel? Whether they let you see them parents or not? [unintelligble] Couldn't see 'em.
[unintelligble]--plastic bags, they wasn't --  even the white people could[?] come in.
They wouldn't run[?] their mouth while they wouldn't give me no clothes or nothin' until Saturday [unintelligble]
[cross talk]
They wouldn't even let me talk to nobody. The whole time I was there, the whole 30 days. [unintelligble] Willoughby Haynes tried to talk to me, and they said no.
Can I make a suggestion, because this is important. Give your name as you say this.
Louisa Banks, They wouldn't even let me talk to nobody. The whole 30 days.
No relatives were allowed to…
They let my uncle come one time and told him to hurry up, because they didn't have but a few seconds.
And out of the 30 days, they let me see nobody else.
[unintelligble]
Ok.
Ok.
[unintelligible] I have ... one time, and I gave him one, and I gave him…two packs, and once I only gave him one.
They were selling those things...
They were selling them back to us.
They were very…
And  selling 'em back to em for forty cents.
[multiple voices of agreement/discussion] Yeah, Forty cents a pack.
[someone Shhs.]
Mother of Nividian[?]. And I can say that I carried quite a bit of food there, and quite a bit of… Um, clothing. But I can say the cigarettes were never carried up as I carried them there.
If I carried a six[?] pack I only got one. And, um, some days they were… mean to us. They cursed at us.
[background agreement]
And your name, your name again, please.
And yesterday,-- Christine Anderson. Yesterday, I went there with, uh, his father, sister, and I.
And, uh, they wouldn't let me in, but they let the sister and the father go in.
And 3 or 4 was going in to see the other people.
But they wouldn't let me go in. I'm his mother.
On the first day, I went to see my son in the morn --
Okay, just give your name again. Ms. Thomas?
Helena Thomas. I told him he suffered with a headache. He said he must have been out of his mind from what he did. That's what he told me.
Oh yeah, and we had to take the bus out, and we had to take showers up under the, uh… ice in a [unintelligble]. Cold hearted. [unintelligble]
Cold water.
Cold water.
The other day -- Harry Malley, your daddy sent us some apples and they got some of em out.
[background voices] Yeah, they sure did.
They opened the package and got them all out of the box. [unintelligble]
I like apples too when they got the...
They got the apples back.
I always sent the, sent the closed bag -- did you receive em like that?
[unintelligible] -- where I could see everything, you know, they was-- they said…
[background laguhter]
Yeah, they said, they would go in there, get barbecue, somebody sent some barbecue to some of they children last Sunday, and they said, "This is damn good barbeque."
[laughter and cheers] Tell 'em what they said!
[unintelligble, group cheers/voices]

About, about four days ago -- about four days ago -- about four days ago -- they started, they started turning the lights on -- off about… You know, about 9 o'clock, they say we was making up too much noise in there, and they told us they're gonna take all the blankets and bring all the mattresses out.
There weren't but 5 in there. And it was 8 of us, you know, 5 with all the, single mattress.
They told us they were gonna quit feedin' us, and quit lettin' our parents see us, and quit lettin' them bring us anything.
Did they ever make any, physical threats?
No, but -- [everyone talking all at once]
Wait, now wait, wait -- let one talk.
Right there, son.
Before we got there, they told me if I didn't tell the truth -- which I was -- they told me that I was lyin, so they said they was going to put me in the --- put me in the --
[other voices] sweat box
Sweat box, where I couldn't see no one, and no kind a light.
They didn't actually do that though, did they?
No.
Alright. Ard?

Let me say one thing. Nick, [cough] let me see, the first week after we went down there, we're aware of, Nick, they -- one of those guys, somebody called them on the outside, and one of them guys shared with him and, 'bout two days after, Ward One, we drove back to hi' daddy, he ran in there and he hit him. And he drove back and he didn't come in.
Yeah but--
He did come in --
[Cross talk]
He did, came back and had him drove back to his daddy. After we all got up and we… went back on the outside. The other one is two timin', they tried to shove around on us.
Do you have any, two or three questions? Mr. --
Yes, um… I'd like to ask you about, uh -- what, recreation privileges did you have?
[Multiple voices] None. None at all.
Were you able to get out of the cell at all?
[unintelligible] We could play cards.
You could play cards. In the cell?
In the cell.
But you couldn't -- you didn't have any outside recreation or anything of that kind.
No, sir.
Couldn't leave the cell.
No sir.
You could leave the cell and go see your parents, but you'd be in another cell.
In another cell.
[unintelligible] Sometimes.
Yeah, sometimes.
How 'bout the food that they gave you there?
[chorus of voices laughing, saying "the FOOD?"; "terrible!"]
Cold --
Cold beans --
Cold pork and beans out the can.
On Sunday.
[unintelligble] -- mashed up with eggs. That's all --
Beans so hard you couldn't have --
They ain't season there a piece of meat.
[shhing, clapping? in background]
Cut in tape?
14:48 Ask the question again.
I'm just asking about breakfast. You had coffee without cream or sugar, is that…
[coughing, unintelligible]
They stopped giving us coffee about...two weeks ago. They stopped giving us coffee.
They wouldn't even give you coffee?
None at all.
Nothing at all. What did you have for breakfast?
[two voices] Grits, bacon, bread, little small pieces of bacon. White bread.
And dry syrup. [Laughter]
But no coffee.
No coffee, they quit giving coffee.
The syrup wouldn't even sweeten the coffee.
How about your singing? Did they discourage your singing in the cells?
Yeah they cursed us, so many times, every night.
"Cut this, that, and the other out. Be quiet, and we gon' turn the lights off from now on. We gon' take your mattresses out and watch you sleep on the concrete in the jail."
--called us all different names.
What did they call you?
I can't call the name --. [laughter]
I think the parents would excuse it this time, go ahead.
No, like we be sleeping....like--
In the daytime …

--in the daytime, we'd be sleeping, and they'd run in there and kick on the door. "All you fuckers get up in here." [laughter] "That's when y'all stay…we'll call at night. Sleep in the daytime." [laughter]
Cut in the tape?
In the door you know, they...kick on the door, beat on the door..
[multiple voices]
Trustees.
16:03 The jailer, we heard the jailer told him to do it.
He told him to beat on the door, wake them [n-word] up in there. [laughter]
Who are the trustees, was he, uh, white?
[multiple voices] Yeah, three white. Three of 'em.
Three, three white trustees.
Bagwell. The one got lice with some of us in the pen the other day.
Who, who?
Bagwell. Ol' Bake.
Turner.
Owens.
--and Owens.
Well now, Mr. Owens, he was -- he was a nice man. [unintelligible] he brought us --  stuff like that, he was a nice man.
He was pretty good. He never did be in[?] much.
Mr. George Guy cussed at me. Called me a "son of a bitch."
[Laughter]
George Guy, the police chief?
That's right, when they came into the city hall that night, when they arrest me, him and Biggie, when they arrest me, he said, "You son of a bitch, you tell us the truth." That's what they say.
